comments.commentBody:
There are still choices. There is the Green Party, there is the Libertarian Party, there is stay at home. There is write in a name such as Mickey Mouse or Bernie Sanders.
Both the Democratic party and the Republican party had other candidates. The Democratic party even had other highly qualified candidates. The Republicans chose the people's choice, the Democratic party crowned an unlikeable candidate and laughed and denigrated the other candidates. They did not listen to the people at all. Hillary may have gotten more votes but that is only because Bernie wasn't even considered viable and was not given any media coverage until the public demand that they do so. (Media coverage is important. Look at what it did for the Donald.) Too bad the Democrats didn't listen.
My choice will be one of the three 4 options in the first paragraph. Oh, and I will support the Democratic female that is running for US Senate in my state.

Your decision not to vote for Hillary Clinton might result in Trump being our next president (and the lower case p was on purpose). I have no great love for Hillary but my dislike of Trump cancels out any animosity I have for her.  I could have liked other Republican candidates, but not enthusiastically. Republicans voted for Trump despite his lack of any experience or policy. Whether you want to face it or not, Clinton is sane and Trump is not.  I liked Bernie until he started on his hate campaign against Clinton and he has no hope of winning the nomination anyway.  Your candidates won't win, as you know, but It's a distinct possibility that Trump will.

Martha, It's NOT the emails. It's the fact that she lies and lies and lies and she did so while she was in a high level government role which threatened national security. And she has lied about other things as well.
Donald may also lie, but has not done so in a job that had the potential to threaten national security. We have NO idea what will happen if he becomes president.
I have to go clean my house something neither of them has ever done.

You say Clinton had a good day, Gail. I say she had a bad week.

While MSNBC has been supportive of Clinton during this campaign, hosts had harsh criticisms after the inspector general released his report.

Mika Brzezinski: It Feels Like Hillary Clinton Is Lying Straight Out | Morning Joe https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bkJE0U8Qby4

Clips were shown of Clinton repeatedly saying during the past year that her “personal email use was fully above board and allowed by the State Department.”

Andrea Mitchell: “It doesn’t hold up. There are so many inconsistencies, including their response yesterday. We now see new emails, never turned over, that the IG found. What’s that all about? … She said [to an aide] we want to make sure that the ‘personal is not accessible.’ There are so many flaws in their argument I don’t see how this is anything but devastating given the fact that they have been making a completely different argument now for more than a year.”

Chuck Todd: “Because of this breach ... I don’t think she could get confirmed, for instance, to be attorney general. The most logical explanation is that she wanted to make it harder for the press and Congress to see her correspondence. So they made the FOIA requests more difficult by doing what? Making sure it wasn’t on a government server. I’ve never been able to accept that [Clinton had the server for convenience] because what is convenient about putting a server in your house? I hate dealing with Wi-Fi in my house. It’s a pain.”

For those salivating to see Trump send Clinton to prison...don't hold your breath.
Politico did a fascinating study of all the similar cases and how they were handled and why. Intention counts in prosecuting these crimes. Inadvertent violations may be stupid, but they are not criminal. Petraeus -- just one of many examples given -- deliberately handed his mistress top secret documents which he stored without permission in binders at home. Read the facts....

http://www.politico.com/story/2016/04/hillary-clinton-prosecution-past-c...
They are using gang mentality not the thinking of an American citizen with obligations to the general welfare of the US.

We have had more than 20 years of media coverage scrutinizing every detail of Clinton and her record, hoping to inflict career-ending damage. Perhaps that coverage has not run as extensively in the NYT as in other publications, but that is far from giving a free pass.
Issa is hardly more than a very lucky car thief.

It has been really really sad that America has had to put up with the radical obstructionist GOP'ers and their weak weak Congressional Theatre acts for all these many years of 2 Obama terms - it would seem that at some point GOP'ers would have been shamed into consulting Master Thespian Jon Lovitz (of SNL fame) to give them some pointers along the way.

Instead, we have people like Committee Chairman Issa (rhymes with hissssss) bumbling and stumbling through bad Congressional Theatre act after bad act, culminating in the reading of ' how to impeach ' from wikipedia:

https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/republicans-hopes-for-an-obama-s...

regarding efforts to strike out at IRS.

Benghazi is more of the same - like Statler and Waldorf watching a really bad Muppets production, we can't wait for the curtain to fall down and close this dreadful theatre GOP'ers have been engaging in, pretending they are actually conducting the nation's business.

Wags,

It's now the Glen Island Harbour Club.
http://www.glenisland-harbourclub.com/

Trying to recapture the old elegance with a British spelling, I guess. But I think it's weathered the years better than A.B. Davis High School, sadly.

My K&E is in some box somewhere, unless Elaine got to it by now.

What do you call a sackbut player? Sackbutter? Sackbuttist? Sackbutisto?

Wiktionary lists "tromboner," but you shouldn't use it in France. You probably shouldn't use it here either.
Trombone is the French word for a paper clip, btw.

Martin, are you feeling horny tonight? Then this guy should be right up your alley.

As for the puzzle it was a Saturday.
Not to be a NITpicker, but back in the day, the NIT was as important as, and sometimes more important than, the NCAA tournament.

Trump's disrespect for the Constitution, the courts and the general rule of law also brings up another disturbing issue: He will never accept a loss in November. His first response to losing the election will be to question the results, and claim the existence of massive evidence of voter fraud throughout the country.

The violence at his rallies is merely a foreshadowing of what's to come.
Irrelevant. It's not Congress's job to give him a free pass on whatever he wants to ram down the country's collective throat. You do know the meaning of "checks and balances," right?

Unfortunately, Paul, as of now the Republicant establishment seems to be embracing him, metaphorically closing their eyes and thinking of England.
Witness yesterdays Profile in Cowardice courtesy of Paul Ryan.

All of what you say is correct, with the one exception that 'the world is just beginning to vet Donald Trump'. He was actually vetted much more broadly abroad than here from the very beginning.
I constantly read French, British and German publications, both from the center left and center right, and not one day went by since Il Trumpolini declared his candidacy that he was not criticized, and mercilessly ridiculed in their press for his incoherent speeches and whipping the least educated into a frenzy of hate against all the 'Others'.
Europeans, including their leaders of both sides of the political spectrum, and the vast majority of their citizens are shaking their collective heads in disbelief over the phenomenon of Trump, one that is often compared to how the Fascist reigns of Il Duce, Generalissime Franco and the Austrian paper hanger came to power.
They used the F-word in relation to Trump much earlier than ever mentioned in any of our press organs.

That Trump is who he is comes as no surprise - it's a big world full of all sorts of people. It's the ones who support him in his bid for the presidency of the United States who worry me. That's who we should be writing and talking about, because those voters live and work among us, we pass them on the street every day -- and they are more of a threat to this country than any terrorist. Terrorists, you keep an eye out for and do your best not to get blown up; Trump supporters are like a cancer, eating up the body politic from within. Let us fervently hope that the nation's immune system neutralizes them before they can do us irreparable harm.

Not knowing what someone is talking about guarantees one entry to the legion of folks with Donald Trump stickers positioned just under the NRA patches on pick-ups all over the scruffiest parts of our sad nation.

Not knowing what someone is talking about is reason enough to vote for a nincompoop for a mentally challenged nematode.

Hillary may have had a good day, but America had a terrific week.

The New York Times - still America's paper of record - has run several serious news stories revealing Trump's shady, vexatious-litigating business style, his fraudulent 'university', his incoherent foreign policy and his first naked attack on a sitting federal judge, who he gratuitously called a 'Mexican' for extra stupid credit.

Trump topped it off on Friday with a California speech where he did his Archie Bunker best to rally the black vote as he said “Oh look at my African-American over here. Are you the greatest? Do you know what I’m talking about ?"

No, Donald, nobody knows what you're talking about.

Instead of looking at your 'African-American over here', how about if we all just agree to look away in horror, Donald ?

Donald Trump is in the slow-motion process of imploding before a live national television audience.

We have five full months of character analysis left, but Hillary has already been vetted for 25 years...we know who she is for better or for worse.

The world is just beginning to vet Donald Trump, and the early vetting is starting to make Hillary look absolutely gorgeous by comparison, not to mention very Presidential.

Five more months to tear away the curtain behind the Wizard of Trump is a long time.

The Trump Implosion may Make America Great Again after all by electing another Democratic President and Democratic Senate and rescuing the Supreme Court from right-wing hijackers.

Every Republican —whether they be members of Congress, a state legislator, a city mayor, the town dog catcher —should be voted out of office if they support Trump. It's one thing to support your party, another to shut your eyes to despotism and authoritarianism because you want your party to win at any cost. Politicians are elected to uphold the Constitution and most of all to serve the people, not to follow party rules blindly and recklessly. Any Republican who supports Trump has in effect reneged on that contract with the electorate.
The Little Sisters of the Poor sued the Department of HHS so they wouldn't have to fill out a government piece of paper for their employees who wanted to add BCP on their policies.
What unites the 20% of Bernie voters who would vote for Trump? Misogyny.

Mark:

Please take your thoughtful "Moonbeam" advice and stuff it in turn. I was there when Reagan passed the baton to Jerry Brown as CA governor, in 1975. I watched his antics there for years, and have watched his reprise of the role. The notion that he's bipartisan is a joke -- he doesn't need to be with a legislature boasting Democratic supermajorities in both houses, bought and paid for by pubic sector unions. His "political problem-solving" consists merely of raising taxes.

And, while he earned the name "Moonbeam" honestly back in the seventies and early eighties, his focus on your train-from-nowhere revalidates the title yet again in HIS seventies (soon to be HIS eighties).

But I've never underestimated him as a populist force: he's formidable; which is why Dems could do FAR worse than nominating him instead of Hillary. Far worse -- for instance, they could nominate Bernie.

New Jersey will seal it for Hillary.
Your comments about Jerry Brown remind me of your Governor's attempt to smear him. Now that was funny.

If 20% of Bernie supporters would vote for Trump (which probably means another 30% would consider it) rather than for Hillary, and Sanders and Trump are such utterly different men with such completely different worldviews and agendas, what is it then that unites that 20%-50% with Trump Republicans? I suggest that it’s a shared disdain for the establishment of BOTH sides that have disappointed so many Americans who haven’t seen their life-prospects improve in so long. Without putting too fine a point on it, when you look up the word “establishment” in your Funk & Wagnalls, you find a picture of Hillary Rodham Clinton. That can’t be good for the architect of Whitewater, even if she DOES edge out Bernie in CA.

Tim spent a fair amount of time on Moonbeam, and I’ve been giving him a lot of ink myself in comments here and there. Given all the talk about the difficulty Bernie is giving Hillary plus the rumors circulating about eMailGate (WHY did the FBI give prosecutorial immunity to the IT guy who set up Hillary’s infamous server?) some are now suggesting that she might not wind up as the Democratic nominee. Well, if the Dems REALLY wanted to toss a wrench into Trump’s juggernaut, it would be with Moonbeam, not Bernie. Regardless of polls, Bernie would lose where with a relatively eMailgate-unscathed Hillary, the outcome would be too close to call until Election Night. But Moonbeam … is a very formidable avatar of the unchained, potted liberati. He’s actually scary.

@gemli

I am not sure if your remark about Trump's temperament is accurate. He is after all, a showman, and it appeals to a certain sect of followers, who want to do the same thing, but are constrained by society. The want to rant and rave, but are not rich enough to do do.

If they work somewhere, the can't do it at work, the don't make enough to take off and attend rallies where they can vent their frustrations, he says what they want to say, but would be chastised in decent society. It is the kind of dialogue you might hear in a biker bar.

He knows who his audience is, and plays to it, gambling that there are enough of the to get him elected. Now the GOP establishment has to support him as he is all they have. It shows just how debased the party has become.

They are dammed if they do, and damned if they don't, and they have earned it with their obstructionism to a president who has really tried to be bipartisan. They have rejected any overtures on his part, and then said he is responsible for the divide. Traditional GOP strategy, blame the victim. It's you fault we can't all get along.
My apathy for soccer can be summed up in a headline, which stated something to the effect of "X team routs Y team, 4-0."  In baseball, one swing can erase 4-0.

I am particularly impressed with your ability to make these claims with no reference or attribution: are you sure of this "absolute fact"? Would you be so kind as to reference your claims with documentation or primary sources?

I didn't think so.
Teleprompter no news conferences in a year.LOL
Thank you, and all the other volunteers – and best of luck!

I took my baby girl to see Ms Clinton speak today at a get out the women's vote rally today. The energy was electrifying. She continued the theme of her speech wth such fire that the whole crowd was mesmerized. Her surrogates gave pitch perfect introductions. It was inspiring. Most importantly, the rally was filled with hundreds of  women volunteers who will do the hard work and heavy lifting it takes to get your candidate elected. Angry tweets and pep rallies don't translate to victory.

Hillary has never criticized Bernie Sanders for continuing to run his campaign.  In fact, whenever she's asked the question, she specifically mentions the fact that she did the same in 2008 when she ran against Obama.

Hillary hasn't criticized Bernie for staying in the race. In fact, she's said very clearly that he should if he wants to, and argued on his behalf that she did as well through the last ballot.

The difference, from the perspective of her supporters, is that he hasn't sufficiently toned down his rhetoric about her alleged negatives, even though he knows his chance of getting the nomination is microscopic (Clinton needs less than 70 delegates total). Thus, the calls for him to get out of the race. Bear in mind that, even if he had dropped out a month ago, he would still have remained on every ballot. So anyone who wanted to would still be able to vote for him.

Hi, Bill P., from another person in wonderful Albany, CA -- Hillary Clinton has never called for Bernie to quit before the primaries are over, though some other Democrats have. But there's a big difference between what Hillary did in 2008 and what Bernie Sanders currently says he's going to do. On June 7, 2008, a few days after the primaries ended, Hillary conceded to Barack Obama because he had around 100 more delegates than she did. She gave a generous concession speech and urged her supporters to start supporting Barack. Then she started campaigning for him. At the convention in August 2008, Hillary was the one who nominated Barack for President. (Google 2008 Democratic primaries" and you'll find a good Wikipedia article on this.)
Bernie Sanders currently says that even if Hillary Clinton is still ahead of him in popular vote and pledged delegates at the end of the primaries, he is going to contest her nomination at the convention in late July and try to persuade superdelegates to overrule voters' preference for Hillary. For Bernie to do that would be, in my opinion, futile and divisive, and would suck energy and resources away from the all-important goal of defeating Donald Trump in November. I hope Bernie will change his mind and, if he is still behind Hillary in popular votes and pledged delegates when the primaries are finished, concede graciously to Hillary and throw his support behind her, as she did for Barack in 2008.

Hillary's candidacy has taken an up-turn.  While it is proper for Bernie to push for all he can get through the Convention, and hypocritical for her to criticize him for doing as she did in 2008, it is encouraging to see that she has learned how to call a Trump a Drumpf.  Or a Dummkopf.  While she has earned criticism for lying about her e-mails, and a hyper-aggressive foreign policy that may have led to Benghazi in the longer run -- with Congressional Republicans unable to find tactical errors there over a period of a few weeks -- her analysis of Trump's incoherence may make voting for her, if her opponent still is Trump, easier to do with a good conscience.
Agenda? He has an agenda?

Say what you want about Trump, it's refreshing to see someone pushing their agenda so forcefully. If Obama had come out as aggressively for tax reform, cap and trade, immigration reform, public infrastructure, anything at all really since his 2010 mid-term loss of Congress, I think we'd be in a different place. There's a leadership vacuum in Washington, and Trump will fill it if no serious leaders have the guts. Even on gun control, possibly the issue he's sought most directly to address, how has he really educated the public? Katie Couric did more in a single documentary than he has in 7 years... I voted for the man twice, but what a disappointment!! Get out there and fight liberals! Conservatives always fight harder because they're fighting for themselves. Liberals are generally doing good for someone else less well off, and it's shows. They always have to keep their dignified air. Gore, Kerry, Clinton, they're all the same. We need more Warrens and Bernies in the fight.

Luettgen - please take the “Moonbeam” comment and stuff it.  California Governor Jerry Brown is everything we want in a politician:  willing to work with the other side of the aisle, practical, incorruptible, educated, realistic.  Sometimes you’d think he’s a Republican!  As a lifetime resident of California, I can tell you that he is a model for bipartisan political problem-solving.

Since clearly the right has always been Lilly white on this matter. What is the most gobsmacking to me is watching one republican after another rolling from violent disagreement with Mr Trump and his policies to lining up:  please look forward to replays of these individuals first condemning and then immediately afterwards indicating their support. Clearly these are individuals with high levels of personal integrity who do not let politics get in the way of principle (sarcasm alert). I am not sure if the term "flip flop" does this justice

Hah, Hillary Clinton didn't do different from Colin Powell or Condi Rice in their gov't jobs.  If there is "fault", it is that of the IT security of the Dept. of State. It was THEIR job to approve the email delivery of the Sec'y of State, or not.  So this entire "snafu" is nothing but DESPICABLE Republican PROPAGANDA.
As my mother might say, "Stick to getting Baltimore functional again, and you'll have plenty to do."  Maybe President Trump will visit the town without pity in 2017, if it's safe by then.

El Donaldo: A Nixon Republican.
Now all he needs to meet the qualify is:
1. Release his tax returns under audit (just like President Nixcon);
2. Continue bigotry (like President Nixon); and
3. Start a trade war with China--instead of building relations like President Nixon did.

He's almost there.... as Meatloaf said:
"Now don't...be...sad...
'Cause-two-outa-three-ain't-bad....

I went to New Rochelle High, just down the street from the venerable IONA College.  But we also had the Glen Island Casino, whose heyday was the '30s and '40s.  Your guy got his break there, so I consider him a landsman.  A decade earlier, one Oswald Nelson's band was big there, along with his singer, Harriet Hillard.  Two good avatar candidates.
